header: This is the last issue of the Perl Weekly for 2011, number #22 since I started it in August. The subscriber list steadily grew to be well over 2000. Mostly with your help.
It was a joy putting these issues together. The small number of unsubscribes and the large number of clicks indicate that most of you have also enjoyed receiving this newsletter.
In the next year I'll have to find new ways to promote the newsletter so it can reach an even larger audience. I shall ask your help in this next year.
In the meantime enjoy your Holidays...

entries.title: FOSDEM 2012 Perl dev-room: Call For Speakers
entries.text: Claudio Ramirez (nxadm, El-Che) writes: FOSDEM is the biggest free and non-commercial European event organized by and for the community. The Perl community has a growing presence at this event that helps promoting Perl and distributing knowledge.  It would be awesome to see some of you offer a talk there.

entries.title: The 2011 Perl 6 Coding Contest
entries.text: The thing is that this contest can be interesting to anyone who like programming and likes challenges. If you are a 'Perl 5 fan' or a Pythonista, forget about it for a minute. What if this was a Haskell contest? Yeah, I know, you would want to do it as that's one of the coolest language. Writing in Perl 6 is even more interesting. See the announcement of Carl MÃ¤sak

entries.title: Not a designer? Get involved with the MetaCPAN logo contest anyway!
entries.text: Olaf Alders offers $400 and eternal glory for the winner of the contest. IF you are not a designer, tell a friend of your.

entries.title: Citrus Perl Release 12
entries.text: Mark Dootson wrote about the new release of Citrus Perl which is a Perl especially designed to build and distribute desktop applications written in Perl.

entries.title: Introducing nginx-perl
entries.text: Alexandr Gomoliako announces the first public release of perl embedded in the Nginx web server. I have not tried Nginx yet but I should.

entries.title: Trying Marpa to parse CSS
entries.text: I am sure some of you are already fed-up with Jeffrey Kegler constantly writing about Marpa. So I am happy to tell you that this time it is Wolfgang Kinkeldei who shows how he used Marpa to parse CSS.

entries.title: STF - A Distributed Object Store
entries.text: lestrrat writes about Livedoor, his employer releasing STF, their internal distributed object store under and open source license. This sounds interesting.

entries.title: TWiki I/O Architecture Explained
entries.text: In the Perl community we mostly talk and read about modules and how to use while in corporations they mostly care about large and complex applications. I think it is very important to read about large and complex open source applications such as Twiki. I'd be very interested in how do they do development and testing of the whole system.

entries.title: Sanitizing supposed UTF-8 data
entries.text: Jon Jensen wrote how he had to convert strings in various encodings, some of them even mangled to UTF-8. He used Encoding::FixLatin and found a few other useful modules for when you need to convert legacy data to UTF-8.

entries.title: Beginning Perl - Sneak Peek
entries.text: Ovid shows how he is explaining recursive subroutines in his new book.

entries.title: one more reason to dislike mutability
entries.text: Usually we see examples on how things should be written so it is very educational that Ricardo Signes (RJBS) shows us an example of a failure. Based on the comments it seems that this particular issue has biten many good programmers.

entries.title: Sending a simple email: the current 'modern' way
entries.text: Steven Haryanto shows how to send e-mail using Email::Sender.

entries.title: Perlito version 8; Perl5 and Perl6 compilers
entries.text: Flavio S. Glock (fglock) announces a new version of Perlito: Perlito is a compiler collection that contains both a Perl 5 compiler and a Perl 6 compiler.

entries.title: The Perl 5.15.6 Epigraph
entries.text: Dave Rolsky has released Perl 5.15.6, the latest development version of Perl. Each release includes an epigraph. Dave explains his choice.

entries.title: 7 Curated Weekly newsletters for programmers, sysadmins and what's in between
entries.text: I posted a list of 7 + 2 newsletter. The JavaScript Weekly and the Ruby Weekly that inspired the Perl Weekly and a few others that had the same inspiration.

entries.title: Public Perl Training Courses in London in February
entries.text: Dave Cross is running Public Perl training courses again.

entries.title: The Perl Oasis
entries.text: January 13-15, 2012, Orlando, Florida, USA

entries.title: Perl Workshop in Israel
entries.text: February 28, 2012, Ramat Gan, Israel

entries.title: German Perl workshop
entries.text: March 5-7, 2012, Erlangen, Germany

entries.title: DC-Baltimore Perl workshop
entries.text: April 14, 2012, Catonsville, MD, USA
